titleStmt.title: A commission or, Position: wherein all English subjects, have their undertakings and indevours for the restitution of his sacred Majesty, unto his throne and dignity, though without commission for the same: proved to be lawfull, and their bounden duty, by the word of God, and the law of the land, and the light of reason; and that the statute law of the kingdome is their protection therein. Intended for the satisfaction of all those, who have ingaged, or shall ingage in the sayd undertaking; and an answer unto all those that urge their want of commission against them. By a lover of peace and truth.
titleStmt.author: Lover of peace and truth.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 19 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: A commission or, Position: wherein all English subjects, have their undertakings and indevours for the restitution of his sacred Majesty, unto his throne and dignity, though without commission for the same: proved to be lawfull, and their bounden duty, by the word of God, and the law of the land, and the light of reason; and that the statute law of the kingdome is their protection therein. Intended for the satisfaction of all those, who have ingaged, or shall ingage in the sayd undertaking; and an answer unto all those that urge their want of commission against them. By a lover of peace and truth.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A COMMISSION OR, POSITION: Wherein all Engli≈øh Subjects, have their undertakings and indevours for the re≈øtitution of his ≈øacred Maje≈øty, unto his Throne and Dignity, though without Commi≈øsion for the ≈øame: Proved to be lawfull, and their bounden duty, by the word of God, and the Law of the Land, and the light of Rea≈øon; and that the Statute Law of the Kingdome is their protection therein.
Intended for the ≈øatisfaction of all tho≈øe, who have ingaged, or ≈øhall ingage in the ≈øayd undertaking; and an An≈øwer unto all tho≈øe that urge their want of Commi≈ø≈øion again≈øt them.

p.hi: By a lover of Peace and Truth.

q.p: Why ≈øpeake ye not a word of bringing the King backe?

div.head: The Po≈øition concerning Loyall Subjects, &c.
div.p: In the in≈øuing di≈øcour≈øe, I am not ≈øo to be under≈øtood, as that I doe believe the mo≈øt noble and gallant undertakers heerein at pre≈øent doe want Commi≈ø≈øion, but the contrary, this being intended for the ≈øatisfaction of tho≈øe that believe otherwi≈øe or may doubt the ca≈øe. TO griefe of heart (deare fellow ≈øubjects) hearing it reported by ≈øome friends, ≈øome enemies unto the peace of our Kingdome, that it is unlawfull and puni≈øhable by the Lawes of the Land, to rai≈øe force and armes for the re≈øtitution of his gratious Maje≈øty without Commi≈ø≈øion: My duty towards God, mine Allegiance unto my Prince, the dictate of a good con≈øcience, and my ≈øervice unto the Common-wealth would not ≈øuffer me to take re≈øt (for the ≈øatisfaction of the Kingdome heerein without ingagem ‚Ä¢ nt in defence of this truth, That it is not onely lawfull, but al≈øo the duty and Allegiance of all and every Engli≈øh man to joyne and endeavour for the re≈øtitution of his ≈øacred Maje≈øty unto his Throne and dignity, though without Commi≈ø≈øion for the ≈øame: Where fir≈øt ob≈øerve, that my meaning is not to maintaine or defend any ≈øubjects what≈øoever, their taking up of armes, that is leavying and rai≈øing up of Armies without Commi≈ø≈øion, and that lawfull too, but in ca≈øe of re≈øtitution of his (now impri≈øoned) ≈øacred Maje≈øty into his Throne and Dignity, and this (by Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtance) I will make good in di≈øpite of all truth oppo≈øers.

By
1. The Law of Nature.
2. The Law of the Land.
3. The Law of God.

1. the Law of Nature makes this good in regard unto
1. His Maje≈øty.
2. The two Hou≈øes.
3. Our ≈øelves.

1. It is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary and lawfull to rai≈øe armes for the re≈øtitution of our gratious Soveraigne, in a re≈øpect unto ‚Ä¢ im≈øelfe, becau≈øe both common policy and duty, binde the Subject by the Statute Law of this Land, to re≈øtraine all manner of ≈øhamefull ≈ølanders again≈øt their King,5.6. Ed. 6. ch. 11. and if to defend him from the virulency of tongue and pen, is the duty of the Subject, how much more to re≈øcue him from the violence of the ≈øword, and
bondage by the hands of Rebells and Traytours? yea and his ≈øacred Per≈øon from all poy≈øon and other danger.

2. In re≈øpect unto the two Hou≈øes (for the Kingdome neither hath nor ever had intere≈øt or concernment, in the Army u≈øually in theThere is no Parliament without a King, neither hath any Authority to rai≈øe an Army in England but the King: See my kingdoms Remedy. language of the bea≈øt, called the Parliament Army) not medling with, but laying a≈øide their Trea≈øon and Rebellion, the Kingdome hath no ty nor obligation unto them, becau≈øe they have betrayed their tru≈øt, and have deprived them by whom they were intru≈øted, as much as in them lay of every part of their greate≈øt happines. viz Their God and ReligioÃÑ, their King & Laws, their Liberties & Immunities, by Tyranny, Oppre≈ø≈øion, and U≈øurpation, and doe refu≈øe and neglect to act and performe any thing tending to their good and benefit, though their owne Oathes, Votes, Prote≈øtations, and Covenants, with their Declarations, and Ordinances, would lead them thereunto; therefore the Kingdome may and ought, moving though it were but upon their owne ≈øaid principles, be≈øides the Law of the Land, to joyne and endeavour for his Maje≈øties Re≈øtitution, and re≈øtoration unto his Throne and dignity.
3. In re≈øpect unto our ≈øelves, the people of England; it is Lawfull for the≈øe Rea≈øons.

1. Every thing is bound by nature to ≈øeeke and labour after the pre≈øervation of it ≈øelfe, and to prevent its Ruine and de≈øtruction, which of this Kingdome is threatned, by ≈øevering and ≈øeperating of the King, the Law and the Kingdome, as hath beene ≈øomtimes maintained by the oppo≈øite party, ≈øee that ever to be renowned Judge Jenkins, p. 175 therefore to prevent Ruine, and de≈øtruction, enjoynes endeavours for the re≈øtoration of his Maje≈øty.

2. Con≈øidering we have by the two Hou≈øes lo≈øt our Birthrights, happine≈ø≈øe, and pro≈øperity, with effu≈øion of much innocent bloud, and the expence of va≈øt trea≈øure, which the Kingdome can never recover without his Maje≈øties freedome, honour, and ≈øafety; without which we ≈øhall never enjoy moment of quiet, nor ≈øafety to our per≈øons, wives, children, nor e≈øtates: and that the King being Medicus Regni, the Phy≈øitian of the Kingdome, without him the Nation is irrecoverably ≈øick; and he being Pater Patriae, the Father of our
Countrey, without him all Engli≈øh men are mi≈øerable Orphans and he being ≈øpon≈øus Regni, the Husband of the Realme, without him all England is a widdow; each whereof, much more all, if not remedied will prove fatall, unto ≈øo notable a free-born people: unto but common rea≈øon therefore the lea≈øt of the≈øe are ≈øtronger, and of greater authority then any paper Commi≈ø≈øion ≈øigned and ≈øealed by the pretended two Hou≈øes, and may move every ≈øerious & ≈øober minded man to joyn, & endeavour for the re≈øtitution of our gracious King: and who≈øoever ≈øhall upon ≈øound and hone≈øt principles, without ≈øini≈øter ends u≈øe his be≈øt abilities to effect the ≈øame, ≈øhall be ≈øure to beget pre≈øent happine≈ø≈øe to him≈øelfe and his fellow Subjects; and ≈øhall de≈øervedly be honoured, and renowned unto eternity, and enjoy pre≈øent favour with God and man.

2. As the Law and light of nature maintaines this verity, ≈øo likewi≈øe the Law of the Land, both rea≈øt and pretended, fir≈øt the pretended Law, the prote≈øtation, Vow, and Covenant, Solemne League and Covenant, with many of their Ordinances, Declarations and Remon≈øtrances ≈øpeake for his honour, with heede unto his Prerogative, and hath often promi≈øed to make him glorious, with ≈øafety, not ≈øecurity of his Maje≈øties ≈øacred Per≈øon and e≈øtate; but to ≈øuffer him to lye in pri≈øon, is to maintaine a power above and again≈øt his Honour, e≈øtate, and Prerogative, and if not timely prevented, will prove de≈øtructive to his Per≈øon, and the re≈øt which is an open breach of all the fore≈øaid pretended Law. Secondly the reall and true Law of this Land upholds this Truth, Stat. 6. Ed. 1. Liege Homage, every Subject owes unto the King, (viz) faith de membro, de vit√¢, & Terreno honore, which is confirmed not onely by the former pretended Law, but al≈øo by the Oa ‚Ä¢ h of ≈øupremacy: which Oath was taken by every man now in both Hou≈øes, though broken by them all; the words wherof to this purpo≈øe are the≈øe: I promi≈øe that hereafter that I will performe all faith, or Alegeance and true obedience to the Kings Maje≈øty, and his Heires and lawfull Succe≈ø≈øors, and according to my power, to helpe and defend all Juri≈ødictions, Priviledges, Preeminencies, and Authorities granted or due, to the Kings Maje≈øty, his Heires, and
Succe≈ø≈øors, or united and annexed unto the Imperall Crowne of this Realme, ≈øo helpe me God, and the contents of this book.

Whoever hath taken this Oath, and doth not to the utmo≈øt of his power, labour to helpe his Maje≈øty out of pri≈øon; mu≈øt needes be as guilty of perjury, as they which keepe him pri≈øoner: this therefore is a ≈øufficient Commi≈ø≈øion, and is firmely made good by the Statute Law of the Land, as it is peremptorily injoyned 26. Hen. 8.2. Yee ≈øhall ≈øweare to beare faith, truth and obedience. all, onely unto the Kings Maje≈øty: to beare faith, truth and obedience; there is Commi≈ø≈øion to doe him all nece≈ø≈øary ≈øervice. All, there the Commi≈ø≈øion is derected unto every Engli≈øhman, onely to the Kings Maje≈øty, there all faith, truth, and obedience unto the two Hou≈øes, and every other power what≈øoever again≈øt or be≈øides his Maje≈øty in England is exploded and it is neither faith, truth, nor obedience to ≈øuffer the Kings Maje≈øty to be a Pri≈øoner; and it was enacted, 14 Edw. 3.5. that all Officers take an Oath, well and lawfully to ≈øerve the King, and his people: Whereas permitting and ≈øuffering his ≈øacred Per≈øon to remaine in pri≈øon in Carisborough Ca≈øtle, is wicked and unlawfull ≈øervice unto both King and people; againe this Commi≈ø≈øion is made good St. 7 Edw. 1. The words are the≈øe. To us (the King not any other) it belongeth, and our part is, through our Royall Seigniory ≈øtraightly to defend force of armour, and all other force again≈øt our peace at all times, when it ≈øhall plea≈øe us, and to puni≈øh them who ≈øhall doe contrary, according to the Lawes and u≈øages of this Realme, and heereunto they are bound to aide us as their Soveraigne Lord at all ≈øea≈øons, when need ≈øhall be. When need ≈øhall be there is their Commi≈ø≈øion, for can there be more need then when a good‚ñ™ learned, wi≈øe, holy, religious mercifull, and con≈øcientious King, is traiterou≈øly and rebelliou≈øly impri≈øoned, and his Kingdome lies bleeding and ga≈øping at the brinck of ruin through Rebellion and Divi≈øions? See Stat. 25. Edw. 3.2. By the Law of the Land when Trea≈øon and Felony is committed, it is lawfull for every Subject, Vid. Judge Jenkins pag. 185. who ≈øu≈øpects the Offendor to apprehend him and ≈øecure him, ≈øo that ju≈øtice may be done upon him according to the Law. Idem p. 176. To deliver his ≈øacred Maje≈øty out of traiterous hands, is every man of the
Lands bounden duty;Reade Judge Jenkins pag. 18. who≈øoever they be that ≈øhall undertake for the re≈øtitution of his Maje≈øty, though without Commi≈ø≈øion, have the Law of the Land for their Protection. 11. H. 7. chap. 1. which you may reade inThat Patriot of England. Judge Jenkins pag. 89. but to incounter ≈øuch in fight as come to ayde the King in his war is guilty of high Trea≈øon: Thus you ≈øee every Engli≈øh Subject hath ≈øufficient authority, and it is his bounden duty though without Commi≈ø≈øion, to joyne and endeavour for the re≈øtitution of his Maje≈øty. 3. This is warranted unto us by the Law of God: it is a maxime among≈øt the Divines, contra Rebelles omnis homo miles, every man is to be a Souldier again≈øt a Rebell; but le≈øt wee faile, let us a≈øcend higher, St. Paul injoynes us to render unto all their dues, tribute unto whom tribute is due, cu≈øtome to whom cu≈øtome, Rom. 13.7. feare to whom feare, honour to whom honour, all which are in the highe≈øt due unto our gratious Soveraigne in his ≈øeverall Dominions. Tribute becau≈øe he is Gods Mini≈øter, cu≈øtome becau≈øe he is head over his people, feare becau≈øe he beareth not the ≈øword in vaine, honour becau≈øe he is our greate≈øt, that is Politicall Father, and therefore is he ≈øtiled Pater Patriae, the Father of the Countrey: all the≈øe dues therefore are due unto him in the fir≈øt place, not unto any of his Subjects, but as their right and claime thereunto, is derived from him by the conveyance of the Law of God and the Land and all the≈øe being primary and principall dues due from us and all his ≈øubjects; how much more a re≈øcue of his ≈øacred Per≈øon out of the Traytours hands, which you ≈øee is ≈øo ≈øtrongly injoyned us all by the Law of the Land? Whereunto St. Peter injoynes obedience. Submit your ≈øelves unto every Ordinance of man for the Lords ≈øake, whether it be unto the King as ≈øupreame, or unto Governours as tho≈øe that are ≈øent of him, 1 Pet. 2.13. Submit unto every Ordinance of man, there mu≈øt be no ≈ølighting nor neglecting the Law of the Land, but ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion and obedience thereunto, for this is mo≈øt certaine that not the Letter or Declaration of the Law of the Land, but the execution thereof. makes it good and profitable; for now by too dolefull and pre≈øent experience, wee may ≈øee that when the Law is mi≈øu≈øed, di≈ø≈øembled with, or layd a≈øide, or condemned, or is done pro
forma tantum, and as they tearme it in France, Par maniere d'acquit only. it will be the certaine ruine (though not at fir≈øt perceived) of the Common-wealth; therefore this mu≈øt be done for the Lords ≈øake, becau≈øe the good of all, is the will of the Lord Paramount, the God of Heaven and earth, and our ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion and obedience mu≈øt be in this order, unto the King as ≈øupreame: impri≈øoning therefore and ≈øecuring his gratious Per≈øon, is not ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion and obedience thereunto, becau≈øe it is an extirpating and expelling his ≈øupremacy:For who≈øoever is impri≈øoned, therein argues inferiority unto that power by which he is impri≈øoned. On the contrary therefore a recovering and re≈øtoring his Maje≈øty unto his ≈øupremacy, being ≈øo ≈øtrictly injoyned by the Law of the Land, is a ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion and obedience to that ordinance of man: But I will come yet clo≈øer who they be that have exploded the ten Commandements (judge deare Reader) which are neverthele≈ø≈øe the rule of every con≈øcientious Chri≈øtians life, the li≈øt whereof is, honour thy Father and Mother, &c. which is the fir≈øt with promi≈øe: and that wee may the better under≈øtand the honour due, let us fir≈øt con≈øider in the contrary di≈øhonour, and this ≈øhall be in Canaan ≈øon of Noah, who dealing undutifully and irreverently towards his Father, procured a cur≈øe; A ≈øervant of ≈øervants ≈øhalt thou be, Gen. 9.25. though his Father in ≈øome things was unexcu≈øable, but a wi≈øer then Noah hath denounced a cur≈øe upon all undutifull children; the eye that mocketh at his Father, and dispi≈øeth to obey his Mother, the Ravens of the vallies ≈øhall pick it out, and the yong Eagles ≈øhall eate it, Prov. 30.17. and if it be ≈øo odious to God and man for a childe to be undutifull unto his naturall Father, how much more for Naturall Subjects, when they impri≈øon their great Politicall Father, and naturall Soveraigne? whom in the receipt of that Homage of feare from his Subjects, God hath joyned with him≈øelfe, feare thou the Lord and the King, Prov. 24.21. but as God hath linckt him≈øelfe with his Vicegerent in that command of feare from their Subjects, doubtle≈ø≈øely were they able, would have linckt them together in pri≈øon; que≈øtionle≈ø≈øe therefore a re≈øtitution of our gracious Soveraigne Lord the King, would be as acceptable in the eyes of the Almighty, as if it were a re≈øtitution of him≈øelfe; and if Gods ju≈øtice will be ≈øo ≈øevere upon cur≈øed cur≈øing
thoughts again≈øt a King, that a bird of the aire ≈øhall carry the voice, and that which hath wings ≈øhall tell the matter, Eccle≈ø. 10.20. What will be his puni≈øhment of tho≈øe that impri≈øon their Liege Lord? How gratious and mercifull on the contrary, will he be unto them that ≈øhall re≈øtore his gracious Maje≈øty? This is an honour both of debt and duty, then which for the pre≈øent Subjects can doe no greater, and is commanded you ≈øee both by the Law of God and the Land, this was the judgement of the childreÃÑ of I≈ørael in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, they were at a ≈øtrife for re≈øtitution of their King. And all the people were at ≈øtrife throughout all the Tribes of I≈ørael, ≈øaying, the King ≈øaved us out of the hands of our enemies, and he delivered us out of the hand of the Phili≈øtins, and now he is fled out of the Land for Ab≈øolom, and Ab≈øolom whom wee annoynted over us is dead in battle; now therefore why speake yee not a word of bringing the King backe? 2 Sam. 19.9.10. It was likewi≈øe Davids judgement, And King David ≈øent to Zadock, and to Abiathar the Prie≈øts, ≈øaying, speake unto the Elders of Judah, ≈øaying, why are yee the la≈øt to bring the King back to his hou≈øe? (≈øeeing the speech of all I≈ørael is come to the King, even to his hou≈øe) yee are my bretheren, yee are my bones, and my fle≈øh; wherefore then are yee the la≈øt to bring back the King? ver. 11.12. who ever thou art then, that art a Chri≈øtian, and an Engli≈øhman, thou ≈øee≈øt not only thy Commi≈ø≈øion and Authority, but thy duty from the Law of God, and the Land, to joyne and endeavour for the re≈øtitution of his Maje≈øty unto his Throne and Dignity; go on therefore ≈øtoutly and couragiou≈øly, God who hath given this Commi≈ø≈øion, will in this cau≈øe keepe thee for him≈øelfe; looke up unto God as thy pre≈øerver and keeper, and unto his Maje≈øty as the centre of all thy earthly hopes in this Kingdome, and then do≈øt thou rightly feare God and honour the King, and ≈øhalt prevaile at the la≈øt.
